answers.answer: "The doctor said exercise and losing weight will REVERSE my diabetes diagnosis/reading, and I will be able to go off the oral medication she is giving me?"People who sustain long periods of above normal blood sugar levels usually remain diabetic. This could be attributed to lifestyle factors or genetic susceptibility - inherited a diabetic gene. Recent studies show a major contributing factor to t2 diabetes is obesity. Weight loss has been shown to "reverse" one back to normal levels in some people, not all. Reversing diabetes is not an absolute it is a possibility. You need to live the lifestyle changes one makes. This includes eating a proper diabetic nutrition, and maintaining normal Lipid panel to weight loss, and daily 30-60 minutes of exercise. Maintain does not mean cheating a little bit, eating a slice of cake or having a sweet drink every now and then will just put you back where you don't want to be. In order to remain diabetes free one must continue living their lifestyle changes. One must always follow doctor's instructions and have annual checkups too.Your glucose serum test results detected prediabetes. However, your 6.6% A1c raised a huge red flag putting you well into diabetes land with an estimated daily glucose average of 143 mg/dl."Thus, could it be a fluke reading? Am I curable? Should I get a 2nd opinion? The doctor didn't even tell me to test my levels or give me a particular diet to follow -- she just said I should lose weight and will be able to go off meds."1. The A1c is not a fluke, it doesn't lie.2. Currently diabetes has no cure. Like I stated above, it is possible to reverse your condition by making and maintaining lifestyle changes.3. The A1c was your 2nd opinion4. Your doctor is not a dietician. Read other threads on this forum. Proper nutrition - foods to avoid and foods to eat - have been mentioned numerous times. If you continue to have problems ask for a referral to dietician and/or diabetes nutritionist to discuss what you can/cannot eat. This includes portion sizes.5. Glucose test meters can be purchased at your local pharmacy, or Wal*Mart and Walgreens for around $10. Meters are good friends. W/o one you cannot tell what your blood sugars are doing.Times to test are:* Preprandial - before a meal. You should be at normal range levels - 60/70 to 99 mg/dl* Postprandial - 2-3 hrs after a meal. Postprandial testing informs you if the food/s you ate are jacking up your levels. Avoid those that do. Diabetics aim for <141 mg/dl, better <121 mg/dl. Of course, optimum levels are within normal range levels.If you decide to obtain a meter carefully read the accompanying instruction sheet. Not all meters are alike, some require calibration others not and so on.If you have further questions post back to this thread. Good luck -

First of all, meds for what? The high blood pressure or the diabetes? Your readings suggest a pre-diabetic state and I am not sure why she would put you on meds. Also, you should have been instructed on how to use a meter and given one by the doctor. If you are on diabetic meds (pill form) then you absolutely need to be checking your blood sugars! If not, you could go into hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) and pass out or worse. So call your doctor back and ask her these questions! Never leave a doctor's office until you know exactly why you are being given a med and how to take it and what to do if you have side effects. You really need to be more proactive and a good advocate for your own healthcare. Get on that phone!

Don't need a meter. I am on Medforum -- which does not lower the glucose/serum. A recent visit before and after a meal show my glucose/serum 113 to 118. Well within the range I've been . . . all my vitals are nearly perfect.Yes, I am totally reversible, actually. A chat with my doctor and another doctor -- have shown this is true for me. I was not diabetic six months ago. This is very new for me. Secondly, I have on a diabetic eating program now through Nutrisystem, where I have access -- daily -- to a Nutritionist.It's going well, I've lost six pounds in just over eight days. Thank you, though, for your opinions.

That is controlling your BG by diet with weight loss, exercise helps too.  However go back to your old habits and your BG will suffer again.  or gain weight and your BG will suffer again or get older (try to stop that one) and your BG will suffer.curable NO controllable YESGlad your control is working.

Why don't you feel that you need a meter?  Testing throughout the day lets you know how you're doing with control.  Not having one is flying blind. You really DO need a meter.  You mention that you're on "Medforum".  Did you mean Metformin?  An A1C of 6.6 is still quite high especially since you're on Metformin.  Imagine what it would be if you weren't taking it.Take it from someone who was right where you were a year and a half ago.  The only way to get out of your predicament is to cease carbohydrate intake as much as possible.  No "White Stuff". That means no pasta, bread, flour products, sugar, rice, potatoes; anything white.  Reduce your carbohydrate intake as much as possible and you'll see astounding changes in your blood sugar as well as your weight.As the poster above states.  Once you have diabetes, any type, you've got it forever.  People often mistake the term "reversable" as curable; it's not.  You've got it forever.  But you can control it, and you can make the insulin that you still produce more responsive.  It takes "sticktoativeness:.  You have to pledge to yourself to avoid carbs at all costs; no cheating.  I still do our ritual McDonald's breakfasts on the weekends.  But I have 2 round eggs, and a sausage patty; practically no carbs.  I live on almonds, peanuts, cheese, turkey snack sausages, and dozens upon dozens of eggs.  I've dialed back on the eggs, but at one point I was eating 20 eggs per week.  The results are my A1C is 5.7 without medication.  I've lost 35 pouinds, and two waist sizes, mearing three.  My serum cholesterol has dropped as well to 155.The beginning of the new lifestyle was literally painful!  I was hungry, I had headaches, and I pee'd up a storm as my body tried to wring out every available carbohydrate.  After a couple of weeks, it's starts to feel better.  I had energy, and the "carb haze" I was in began to lift,and I felt good.  The whole time, I tested three or four times a day, learning what foods were ok, and what foods spiked the reading.If I can do it, you can too.  I was a carb junkie with daily bag of M&M's on my desk, a cookie or two as my body fuel.  You just have to get your body to switch to burning your stored fat instead of available carbs, and you'll see dramatic losses in BG levels, and weight.

By the way, your Nutrisystem diet is sort of doing what I explained above, but unfortunately it's still allowing a significant amount of carbohydrates in your diet.Let's say that you have a Nutrisystem meal consisting of chicken and rice.  Low fat, and It might be good for someone who wants to lose weight.  But any white stuff that you (or I) consume will be scarfed up by our bodies.  Nutrisystem helps by reducing the number of calories you take in, and therefore the amount of carbohydrates as well.  If you want to see an impact on your BG's, you've got to cut the carbs out as much as possible.

question: All right, I'm getting mixed messages.My glucose, serum is 117, my A1c is 6.6. I'm going to be 49-years-old in two weeks; I have been overweight and obese off and on since age 33.Last year, give or take a month or two; and before that my blood sugar has always been "normal". I ended up with high blood pressure, for the 1st time, about two years ago. I seem to be in full menopause, since October 2011.The doctor said exercise and losing weight will REVERSE my diabetes diagnosis/reading, and I will be able to go off the oral medication she is giving me?Another person said there is "no way" to reverse diabetes. My only family members with diabetes was my paternal aunt and uncle. No one else has ever had it.Thus, could it be a fluke reading? Am I curable? Should I get a 2nd opinion? The doctor didn't even tell me to test my levels or give me a particular diet to follow -- she just said I should lose weight and will be able to go off meds.
title: Diabetes: Am I curable or not?
